content.body: I wouldn't mind if I had *gotten* anywhere in the arguments.
AryehGregor: do you understand the RDFa validation points?
foolip, what
that Manu is making
Possibly not.
me neither, will ask for clarification so that we can steal any good ideas
I'm assuming that RDFa has some automatic validation mechanism like DTDs are to XML, except maybe more powerful.
So you have some language where you can see "this attribute must have only these values" or whatnot.
perhaps it's just RDFS
that would make sense I guess
On a random note: who decided that GNOME Mines should be classified under "Games > Logic"?  Someone who never played Minesweeper in their life?
Makes sense to me, since it's almost entirely logic
other than random guessing at the start
it's not random guessing at the start really
Except for the fact that if you actually play it, you see the right spots by reflex and never have to apply logic?
the first click should be guaranteed not to be a mine
by reflex?
AryehGregor, Minesweeper is entirely logic based.
More or less.
The second click often has to be a random guess :-)
Philip`, not in the GNOME version.  The first click is always guaranteed to have no adjacent mines, so it reveals a whole area.
AryehGregor: you just mean, you can work it out by using the visible information?
AryehGregor: sounds logical to me
AryehGregor: That's just applying pattern-recognition to determine the logical solution without having to recompute the logic every time
the windows version is not guaranteed to have no adjacent minds. Often, you'll click a square that just gives a 1, making the next click a random guess. Other times, you'll get a large area cleared
a) On many/most large boards, you end up having to guess at some point late in the game.
I normally hit the four corners first and then proceed
AryehGregor: With a sufficiently high density of mines, logic *is* requires at some points.
And yes, at least one guess becomes required in many boards.
b) It ends up being mostly pattern-recognition, with only a few small spots of logic required now and again.
I normally just edit C:\WINDOWS\WINMINE.INI to get the top score
wonders if there's a Minesweeper for Mac
True.
(This was quite a while ago, though)
pattern recognition isn't logical?
c) Any decent player will win every board unless forced to guess.  The only challenge is getting the fastest time.
it might be simple, but it's still logical
GarethAdams|Home, by that interpretation, every game could be put into "Logic".
AryehGregor: poker isn't
I'm not sure how (c) is a point against it being in the Logic category.
AryehGregor: Pinball couldn't
TabAtkins, because the challenge in the game has nothing to do with logic.  It's a twitch-based game.
snakes and ladders isn't
feels sorry for readers of Wikitech
GarethAdams|Home, sure poker is, you have to logically evaluate your opponent's reaction to various possible options of facial expression.
Until you build your pattern recognition skills, logic is certainly required to deduce some locations.
foolip: I'd assume people who live in proximity to wikis are quite used to loud arguments by now
Philip`, sure it is, you have to logically compute the physical trajectory of the pinball given your timing in hitting the flipper.
And even then, there are some configurations that I know I've run into that aren't pattern-recognizable without an absurdly large (for a human) pattern database.
Philip`: hehe, possibly
AryehGregor: You appear to be using "logical" as a completely meaningless term
GarethAdams|Home, snakes and ladders . . . you have to . . . logically . . . figure out how to rig the die appropriately.
AryehGregor: there's no mapping of facial expression to poker hand
or at least I can't work out a meaning that would apply in that situation
AryehGregor: so it;s not something you can logically deduce
Philip`, well, yes, that's my point, practically anything is logical if "pattern recognition" counts as logical.
Anyway, the point is, the game is reflex-based, it's not a puzzle game.
It's recognising logical patterns
AryehGregor: getting a high score is reflex based. the game itself is logical

I've had situations where I've had to sit down and say "Okay, that 3 implies that there are at least two mines in this area, which is covered by a 5, which already has a mine marked, and also partially overlaps the area of this 2â€¦"
and not e.g. recognising cats vs dogs
TabAtkins, yes, once in a while.  But it does not belong in the same category as, say, sudoku.
(not that I play sudoku)
Philip`, define "logical pattern".
Pfah.  Sudoku is nothing more than pattern-recognition.
AryehGregor: A pattern a compute can easily deduce
There are a handful of very simple patterns to apply to the board to solve it.
AryehGregor: Sudoku is reflex-based pattern recognition if you're good at it :-p
sudoku is a reflex game
Okay, so let's just agree that "Logic" is a stupid category and be done with it.
I'd rather agree that your use of "logic" is wrong and bad.  ^_^
Anyway, off to play video games!  Wee!
I'll happily agree that Logic is a useful category that normal people would understand as being a sensible way to distinguish minesweeper and pinball
Feh.
notes that AryehGregor is continuing his theme of arguing with people and getting nowhere ;-)
On a different note, I commend the GNOME developers for managing to make a Minesweeper implementation that's visibly slow and unresponsive.
Philip`, :(
putting games into categories is just pattern recognition
AryehGregor: Maybe you need a faster GPU
It's quite a graphically intensive game, particularly with large grids
Also, GNOME Calculator takes about as long to start up as Chrome.
That's with my tabs from last time remembered.
srsly wtf.
Are these all Mono applications?
I doubt it.
It's impressive if they make it slow without pulling in a giant framework like that
I read in a Chromium developer discussion that it's because it checks tons of paths for icons or something.
$ strace gcalctool 2>&1 | grep ENOENT | wc -l
That's not it, though: $ strace /opt/google/chrome/google-chrome --disable-plugins 2>&1 | grep ENOENT | wc -l
Oh well.
goes to play Baldur's Gate 2
saved a couple of seconds from his game's startup time by moving some code (FAM directory watches) into a separate thread
Synchronous IO is really painful :-(
digs into projecteuler.net

is in a customer support "chat" with t-mobile when the support person just wrote "I can really appreciate the concern in needing to get this taken care of for you.  I would feel the same way if this were to happen to me,Customer Name."
Haha.
haha
no freakin way - haha
and apparently she can only add $35 to my account per day
so since the error they made was $67, it'll take two days
hate to know what happens if they lose a $3500 payment
That's what you get when there are so few sellers and such high transaction costs to switching.
(switching providers, I mean)
google voice ftw
though to be fair the high transaction cost in switching appears to be because becoming a customer is SO DAMN HARD
and not so much the phone number issue
Don't people usually buy a phone with a plan and automatically become a customer?
annevk's open ID page includes a stylesheet with the Link header - could javascript be included the same way?
mikekelly: no
is that something that's been rejecteed?
<link rel=script> has been proposed and rejected; i don't think anyone has proposed including script from http headers
that seems like a security nightmare
why is that?
just curious
why does that seem like it woul dbe asecurity nightmare I mean :)
(By "just curious" I assume you mean you'll spend the next two hours arguing for the feature? :-) )
ppppretty much.
injecting http headers somehow (maybe using a linebreak in x-forwards-for)
AryehGregor: i bought a sim card with a plan and they told me it had an error, then tried to buy a sim card with a plan again and they didn't credit my account with the amount i paid
nn
Ah.
nn
if you're injecting headers could you not just modify the body?
mikekelly: maybe
lol.
:D
Hixie, seriously, what is wrong with the telco's on the US?! They seem to have so many crazy ways of operating
yeah apparently being a bandwidth provider in the US requires you to be incompetent
it's probably an FCC regulation or something
I suppose I can't really laugh. I've had enough trouble with Apple support recently, and the guy on the phone today seemed totally uninformed about the issues.
Lachy: Manu says hi to your arm
not really, he says "PS: Tell Lachy that I hope his arm feels better soon. :)"

my Time Capsule died, and the result of the conversation ended up being that I have a choice: 1. Get a new Time Capsule and lose all the data on it; or 2. Open it up, pull out the disk and put it into a new enclosure, but lose the warranty
oh, that's nice of him, I guess.
was this in an e-mail discussion, or some private chat between you two?
in the Wikitech thread
ok, I'll find it later as I read through it.
yep
Lachy: it's a backup, why does it matter what's on it?
(also, dude, get a drobo. anything relying on a single disk is just silly at this point.)
Drobo?

it's a hardware enclosure for 4 hard disks that uses a proprietary raid-like solution for redundancy, in which you can hot-swap drives and expand capacity by adding more drives or increasing the size of any of the drives.
Hixie, because I haven't been using it just for time machine backups
oh.
well then you're not using it per apple's recommendations. :-P
then it truly is a time machine, it brings you back to the state of your last full backup!
apple's stuff only has great tech support so long as you follow steve's vision
yeah, well. it doesn't matter. I'll just get a cheap drive enclosure, and I still have a usable 1TB disk
(if you deviate from the Path, things go poorly)
so i didn't lose much, since I wasn't really using the Time Capsule for its airport functions
ah
also, I might be able to get the power supply fixed
Hixie, why not just use software RAID?
AryehGregor: well, it requires software support, and it doesn't let you mix-and-match drives or hot-swap them while the machine is running
AryehGregor, because the Drobo is so much better
(indeed, while the disk is in use)
I have one too
Hixie, software RAID lets you mix-and-match drives and hot-swap them while the machine is running.
At least, good software RAID (by which I mean Linux).
AryehGregor, having a dedicated hardware raid handle it is useful since it doesn't waste CPU resources on managing the disks
I have one RAID10 partition on two 500G disks, and one RAID1 on an 80G SSD and a 160G normal hard drive, set to read only from the SSD and delay writes to the hard drive.
Lachy, CPU overhead for RAID is typically trivial, especially if it's not RAID5 or 6.
I can hot-swap drives using regular old SATA hotplug.
Raid 5 or 6 are the better alternatives though
Only if you really need the space.
I do need the space
Also, only useful if you have three or more drives.
Well, for RAID5/6 the CPU usage is still typically not much at all.
I have so many terrabytes of DVD rips and downloaded shows, I can't waste any of it
Can you put your root filesystem on this Drobo thing?  What interface does it use, eSATA or something?
it also depends what you're using it for.  I have a RAID 1 and a RAID 0 setup on in PC, with 2 disks each, which. One for the system, one for other user data.
s/on in/in my/
RAID0 is lame.  I hate the thought of downtime just because some stupid disk failed.
(even for my desktop, yes)
but I can't possibly have a RAID within my MacBook Pro or iMac, since their hardware just doesn't support it
What?  You can use software RAID on any hardware.
At least, if you use a decent OS.
Er, unless you only have one disk, I guess.
RAID0 is good if you just care about the performance, rather than worrying about drive failure
Wikipedia uses/used RAID0 for all its database servers!
But they're all replicas, so . . . worst that happens is the site goes read-only for a while until a sysadmin promotes a slave to master, if the master fails.
AryehGregor: i guess you do the software raid with some sort of external disk enclosure?
AryehGregor: or...?
Hixie, no, I just open up my computer and replace the drives.
SATA hotplug works fine for internal drives.

I'd still need some external enclosure to hold all the disks, so I may as well pick an external enclosure that handles all the raid stuff transparently for me, regardless of which machine I'm accessing it from
Just don't brush against the fans, they can sting.
AryehGregor: my two drobos are connected to a mac mini. The mac mini is about the size of one of the 7 disks.
so they ain't gonna fit
Mac Minis are laptops, the size of a disk?
only uses a desktop, currently.  Would probably not put anything on a laptop that he cared about.
no, Mac Mini's about about 20cm, about the size of an Airport Extreme square Macs
ah, I messed that sentence up
no, Mac Mini's about about 20cm square Macs, about the size of an Airport Extreme
20 cm is 8 in, so that's . . . small.  But more than twice as wide as a disk.
AryehGregor: i was exaggerating a bit :-)
http://www.apple.com/macmini/
Okay, just checking.
Height:
2 inches (5.08 cm)
Width:
6.5 inches (16.51 cm)
Depth:
6.5 inches (16.51 cm)
Weight:
2.9 pounds (1.31 kg)1
good evening
doesn't know anything about Mac, except they're shiny and have bash and OpenSSH preinstalled these days.
very shiny!
Give me an Internet-connected computer with SSH, and it'll do, at worst I can SSH into my desktop to do any real work.
Or one of my servers.
hates using Windows on public computers somewhat more than Mac for this reason: no real command line.
windows machines have DOS and telnet. What more would you need?
ducks
They don't have DOS.  Do you mean cmd.exe?
AryehGregor: that's what i always do. The only apps I have running on this mac right now are Terminal with SSH sessions, Chrome for the Web, and a VNC client.
(i use vnc to control itunes running on the aforementioned mac mini which acts as my tv)
Hixie, hah.  So you do all your work on servers, or you have a desktop somewhere you're SSHd to?
most of my work is done in emacs and pine on hixie.ch (aka whatwg.org)
When I'm at school I generally do assignments with vim and pdflatex remotely.
(so actually on my desktop)
AryehGregor, yes, of course. It's still supports the same old DOS commands
Lachy, DOS is the name of an OS, not a command line.
well, I was using the term loosely
That's like calling an elephant a hippopotamus because they're both big and gray.
what is the name of the shell used in DOS?
That's like calling a hippopotamus a Dorian.
geez. No need to make such a big deal out of the terminology.
cmd.exe.
I think.
Assuming it had a name, back in the day.
foolip, I don't think it has a separate name. It's easiest to just call it the dos shell. AryehGregor, that's just the name of the executable
"DOS shell" is probably right, yeah.
Lachy, c'mon, this is a software standards channel, you expect to get away with conflating a shell with an OS?
yes, I do
Rats.  Foiled.
I think I still have a copy of DOS 5 lying around, though probably back in Aus. I wonder if it still works, or if the floppy has given up.
I would hate Windows so much less if it had bash and all the standard GNU utilities installed by default.
And if it had some equivalent to apt-get.
. . . and if it were Linux, I guess.
the windows equivalent to apt-get would require a credit card number as a cmd line argument ;)
I read the FAQ for Intel's SSD cleaner program thing recently.
Last question: "Q: Will there be a Linux version available?  A: No, we're just going to get this functionality built into the stock kernel."

That's so totally representative of Windows vs. Linux.  Windows: install some dubious third-party program to do anything, probably containing malware or at least nagware, unless it costs money.  Linux: works out of the box (if at all, admittedly).
My father was impressed when he plugged in his iPod to a Linux laptop and it popped up an iTunes imitation, preinstalled.
apt-get has such an aweful UI
*awful
In what way?
well, it's a command line, for starters. And the GUIs I've seen for it have not been designed for user friendliness
I think the iTunes AppStore model should be adopted for computer software, except without the DRM
The Ubuntu Software Center is fairly user-friendly.
So was their old one, Add/Remove Applications.
Of course you can't add/remove arbitrary packages with those, you have to use Synaptic for that, which is pretty awful.
maybe they've improved it since I last tried ubuntu a couple of years ago
but I still hate ubuntu, since it's so ugly and gets even the most basic UI things wrong
The Software Center is new in 9.10.  They plan to improve and expand it in the future to be a single central well-designed package management GUI.
You mean compared to other Linux distros, or compared to Mac/Windows?
well, compared to other linux distros, it's not so bad. But compared with Mac and Windows, it's horrible to use
I don't use Mac much, but it seems only slightly worse than Windows if you stick to very common tasks.  If you stray off the beaten path, though, you very quickly end up at a command line.
I'm curious to know what particular things you had in mind, though.

it's equivaelent to Windows Explorer or Finder (whatever it's called in Linux) was really bad, since it had no simple tree view pane (I even have this complaint about Mac, but at least column view is acceptable)
This is where I start saying "Oh, I dunno, I always use the command line for that."
right. Being forced to use the command line for even simple file system navigation is a pain
I'm not even sure what a tree view is.  I can't recall ever using that on Explorer.
In Explorer.  Windows.  You know.
(BTW, the GNOME file manager is Nautilus, KDE's is Konqueror, Xfce's is Thunar, . . .)
Tree View is the left column http://www.enriva.com/images/screenshots/windows_explorer.gif
Oh, that.
I'm not sure I ever used that in my life on Windows.
that's the most efficient way to navigate around in Windows Explorer.
Konqueror has a column-view thingie that seems to look vaguely like I remember Finder looking like.
Although I don't know, since I rarely use Mac.
Aha, thunar has what you want.

another thing I hated was the mouse drivers sucked. No matter how I adjusted the speed, it was never right. It was always either too slow or too fast. It seemed to lack the intelligence that the Windows drivers have
GNOME usually avoids giving you options like tree view vs. normal view.
Really?  Odd.  Never noticed that.
http://thunar.xfce.org/images/filewindow-6.png
perhaps your used to the inferior mouse driving. Most people don't adjust their mice speed anyway and put up with the RSI-inducing defaults.
It seems the same as Windows, anyway.
well, that's an improvent. But still ugly as hell
*improvement
using keyboard to navigate most of the time in Mac OS X finder.
the font is terribly large and the letter spacing is too much.
Heh, I guess everyone has different preferences.  I don't care much about aesthetics, and am happy with command lines.
I don't mind command lines to do some things. But i can't possibly handle doing everything in command lines
I use GUIs for IRC and web browsing, that's it.  I do basically everything else by command line.
Well, a few other random things I also use GUIs for, like FTP.
a lot about the UI prefs depends on habits.
I used to use a GUI for FTP stuff. But since there are no good FTP clients for Mac, I mostly just use scp and ssh
I do that too, except when I have to deal with web hosts where I only have FTP access.
I don't deal with web hosts that don't offer shell access any more
Lachy: did you try the finder for ftp?
I don't except for my synagogue's website, which I manage.
I tried Nautilus for FTP, but it didn't work well, can't remember the details.
I could probably just find a command that syncs files over FTP, like scp for FTP, with some kind of login caching.  Then I wouldn't have a use for Filezilla.
I wonder if any of my old code is still in Nautilus
Probably, if you submitted any noticeable amount.  It's amazing how old code sticks around forever.
Until you want to burn it with fire.
just ran across a JS file in MediaWiki that had UA checks for IE4 and NN4, srsly
I was one of the main developers of Nautilus in the early days
but I have no idea how much it's been rewritten since then
Neat.
hello
html5 can play streaming?
video?
in theory
Hixie, thank you
well...
I want look to html5 streaming sample site
http://www.youtube.com/html5
thanks, but it is not streaming
what do you mean by "streaming"_?
on demand video play
how is that not on-demand video playback?
example, use Flash media server or windows media server
oh
that's purely a server-side issue
html5 doesn't define the server-side aspect of video playback
eli__, what exactly do you want ?
I want streaming boardcasting by use html5's video tag.
eli__: as Hixie says, that's already theoretically possible. You set the video source to a network resource and there's a chance the backend will attempt to stream it.
thank you everybody.
I don't know about video tag.
for example in youtube/html5
it use <video src="http <- http protocol
I knew that streaming protocol is not http
you can use whatever protocol you want (assuming the browser supports it) -- the spec doesn't require any particular protocol
HTTP can be used for streaming, actually
though it's not especially pretty
really?
oh, thank you very much
eli__: It is up to the browser (or more specifically, the multimedia backend) to determine if it can start playback before it has downloaded the entire media file
http://www.youtube.com/html5
is this site streaming? or just download and play?
streaming
and use http protocol?
yes
be not progressive downloading, it is on demand streaming, right?
eli__: This depends on the browser
everybody so kind
thank you
eli__: But for example, I have an experimental webkit build which supports RTP streamed media
(well, theoretically anyway, I haven't tested it)
but you could have <video src="rtp://...">
sorry to little question, nickyoung
I check youtube.com/html5 web page
it has "<video width="640" height="360" src="/demo/google_main.mp4?2" autobuffer> " in source
yep
and the link can download movie
this is probably a progressive download, not on demand
you would need to use something like a rtsp:// uri for on demon
on demand*
foolip: what do you think of making the spec explicitly drop hidden="" subtrees from the microdata processing?
rtsp is window media server's protocol, right?
RTSP is a standard protocol: http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2326
eli__: I don't think window's media server uses it by default
eli__: but I am no expert on window's media server :)
oh, I had remember miss information. thank you hixie
nickyoung : :)
eli__: Some googling suggests Window Media Services uses MMS - a proprietary streaming protocol
:) thank you
I am curious now to try rtsp streaming on my webkit build
why do you want rtsp protocol?
another protocol? for example, rtmp?
is html5's base?
Oh boy, more poetry
rtsp is an open protocol, plus, it's the only one which supports proper on demand streaming, I think
Hixie: as I understand it, the Mac OS X kernel participates in managing the file system on a Drobo
i don't see how it could
Hixie: I got a ReadyNAS instead in order to have a distinct kernel for the filesystem
the only thing you need software for with the drobo is reformatting it to greater than the 2TB default partition size
Hixie: how does Mac OS X access it?
I thought it showed up as a local volume
USB storage or firewire storage
Hixie: but USB and Firewire give you a block device and the OS manages the filesystem, right?
no idea
but my drobos worked fine before i installed the software
my assumption was that the OS default file system implementation was used
hence no installation required
my point is that Mac OS X *will* crash
and HFS+ *will* get mangled
so I prefer to have ext3 under a distinct kernel on the ReadyNAS and have the Mac talk to it over the network
a pure block device wouldn't know how much space is free, surely
the OS thinks it's a 16TB external disk, with about 14TB free
yet the drobo has LEDs showing how much is really free
I don't know how the Drobo works
so i don't know how they did it, but it doesn't seem like the kernel has that much say on what is going on
but if it shows up as a USB/Firewire disk, it seems to me that the kernel of the host computer has to be participating in file system access
is full text search going to be in the database spec?
it's in gears, and it's helpful
tiglionabbit: database spec is pretty much stalled since microsoft and mozilla refuse to implement it (assuming you mean the sql one)
they could have the device know about a few file systems to read the device for free space (and to re-RAID it when needed)
hsivonen: dunno
hsivonen: so far i've had plenty of hard disk issues, but none relating to Mac OS X screwing over the disk
hsivonen: only hardware issues
though one of my damaged disks is in a state where if i plug it into a mac computer the mac hangs because the kernel goes mad trying to do something with the journal
(which it can't since the disk is dead)
and i can't get a mac to reformat the disk
since it immediately tries to fix the disk, thus hanging until i unplug the disk...
Hixie: sure, but it's in webkit already -- does it have any full text search extensions though?
dunno what the status of implementations is
It's nice to see that the new formal process is being properly taken advatnage of
are there any plans to make tablet pressure and sub-pixel positioning a javascript event property?
not concrete plans
every few months someone says we should, but they never actually stick around long enough to write a spec :-)
heh
part of the problem is we don't actually have a spec for 'click' and 'mousemove' currently
well what do you need in the spec?
oh really
or 'keydown' and 'keypress'
that's all non-standard?
non-standard or very vaguely specified
worst part is the mouse button numbers
which are different between browsers
guess that should be pinned down first
Hixie: Would you recommend people to start using the html5 doctype and the current spec?
the doctype certainly
and the spec, for features that were in html4, also certainly -- the html5 spec is far better at describing those features than html4 was, even in its current draft form
i would be careful with the new features though
Yea, exactly my opinion.
Thanks :)
e.g. i wouldn't use <article> yet (though many people are doing so, so what do i know)
if IE supports a feature (e.g. onhashchange), it's pretty stable
I'm curious -- is there anything stopping web browsers from implementing <script type="text/python"> ?
I guess a spec for how the dom should work in other languages perhaps
a spec, a reason, time, and money :-)
is there any reason why <article> or <arbitrary-tag> wouldn't work already?  They have been style-able in gecko and webkit for some time now, and I think there's some way to get IE to do it too
does html5 have instructions for what should happen when unknown tags are encountered?
you have to use hacks and styles and stuff to use things like <article>
html5 defines everything like that, yes
should make it easier to introduce new elements later
Hixie: do you have a preliminary guess of where the about:blank stuff might be going?
no, but i have scheduled friday to fix it
great
hsivonen: so I notice that a year or so ago George submitted a jing patch that improves reporting for missing-attribute and missing-element cases
http://code.google.com/p/jing-trang/issues/detail?id=35
MikeSmith: yeah. I had hoped to see the patch on trunk by now
hsivonen: James seemed to not want to land it until some revisions to PatternValidator get made
http://code.google.com/p/jing-trang/issues/detail?id=35#c1
(James' comment)
hsivonen: but there are a couple of problems with that patch as implemented
one is the format of the error messages it emits
ideally, the expection objects would carry enough data for formatting the message on the application side
for example, for <link> it will give you: "[href, rel] required attributes missing from element link"
yeah
so the other problem is that it does not provide enough information for at least one case I can think of
which is the case of <object>
where the requirement is basically an OR case
a data attribute OR a type attribute
what does it provide in that case?
same as for the link case -- it just emits, "[data, type] required attributes missing from element object"
his implementation just adds the attributes to a Set
on then it calls toString to dump that
Hixie: it wouldn't really add to complexity since we're already cutting subtrees based on the precense of itemscope
ah. I wonder how hard it would be to distinguish "all of these" and "one of these"
HTML5 doesn't have "one of these groups", IIRC
hsivonen: maybe not so hard. I'll take a look at it a bit more and see
foolip: i have no idea what you're responding to :-)
hsivonen: or I guess maybe I should ping George about it first
Hixie: 'what do you think of making the spec explicitly drop hidden="" subtrees from the microdata processing?'
MikeSmith: or maybe ping James and George both in the bug report
hsivonen: OK
however, I'm not quite sure what good it would do, it would most certainly cause surprise to some people
ah
brb
since CSS selectors, getElementById, etc won't ignore that which is hidden="", my vote would be no
but I admit to not entirely understanding the purpose of hidden="" to begin with
Hixie, maybe I'm misunderstanding something, but your response here about nested vocabularies seems confusing http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Jan/0905.html

You wrote: "I think it's better to just use itemtype="" everywhere you want to start a new vocabulary" - but in the vCard example foolip gave, the nested adr stuff isn't a new vocabulary. I thought foolip's idea was that it should default to inhereting the itemtype

Lachy: adr is a "new vocabulary" for the purposes of that sentence
sorry for being ambiguous
i really meant a new set of name-value pair names
well, it shouldn't be. That seems very unintuitive to require the author to repeat the same itemtype again, and I don't expect most authors using the vCard vocabulary will remember that
Lachy: no what i'm saying is that md-vcard, if it wants to work with rdf, should require that the adr types have their own types
different than the vcard type
since they're not vcards but addresses
but they're part of the same vcard vocabulary
only to the same extent that the "reload()" method on the Location object is part of the Window object
so, if an author doesn't care about the RDF conversion, can they get away without using an explicit itemtype, and still express the semantics they want?
sure, that's what md-vcard does
ok. It still seems weird that the semantics that are expressable through md-vcard, can't be mapped to RDF in a sane way by default
they could, just not using the vocabulary-agnostic rdf conversion algorithm
even the work vocabulary can't really be converted naively -- you have to apply extra rules to get it into its "proper" RDF form
(those rules are actually provided, though)
a lot of this is a result of RDF's complexity
e.g. using URLs everywhere
i suppose we _could_ automatically map the adr properties to URLs by concatenating the "path" to the property
hm, no, that wouldn't work
there'd be no way to guarantee uniqueness
(if the above doesn't make much sense to people reading archives, it's because i wasn't very eloquent.)

anyway
We have been looking at different APIs on desktop side
it seems everyone uses push

all I'm saying is that it makes much more sense for the API to be something like audio.synthesizeSound(...); and have it play immediately, rather than having the polling method just waiting for something to be returned
except for JACK
whose developers say push is not a good idea because at the bottom you always have the sound device that is pull
and you can implement push on top of pull easier than the other way around
however JACK is really realtime critical
if some process doesn't return the sound to it in time, it will kick the process out
"no more sound for you"
JACK seems to have different requirements to most normal audio systems, where it doesn't matter so much if there's a glitch and you lose a few milliseconds
aaargh. the difference in length between lang and LeftAngleBracket changes line wrapping, too
Doing anything real-time based on JavaScript seems like a futile idea :-)
so push is probably the way to go then
and there should probably be just one channel out
stereo
if you want mixing, do it yourself
but stereo is 2 channels
one stereo channel
I suppose it'd be nice to be extensible so we can do surround-sound output in the far future
We also looked at this
the conclusion was
(rather than hard-coding the stereo assumption)
there is no way to extend stereo into being surround
and we'd probably want to design the API to be flexible enough to handle multiple channels, even if the first version of the API only supports L and R
surround is something completely different
it doesn't need to be part of the same API
if you do that in future, you may as well define a new API
I suppose it'd be nice to support mono for e.g. iPhone applications where you don't care much about audio quality and do care about processing time
We also thought about that
a function returning sound returns a pair of channels
(left,right)
if you want to save cpu and do mono
just have the same reference on both sides
the API can still be stereo

so that would be four frames of stereo sound

the reason why we want to have only one stereo channel going out is
